page.title: 05NEW ROSSINGTON
page.content: New Rossington to the east of the settlement, was designed as a 'garden village' for colliery workers and for many years was thought of as a good example of town planning, it has an unusual design with the roads and houses in concentric circles. The first pit houses were built in the 1920's they are mostly in terraces or small blocks each with its own garden. Some of the streets are named after men involved with the opening of the coal mine _ Norman, Deacon, Ellis, McConnel, Firth and Streatfeild. After the Second World War three new housing estates were built for the Council and the National Coal Board. The facilities, for the community include a shopping centre, market, welfare club, sports grounds, churches, memorial hall, health centre and library.
